Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Equatorial Internal Gravity Wave Shear, Strain, Instabilities and Mixing--A Moored Process Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the physics of instabilities that lead to the unique strong turbulent flux below the equatorial cold tongue is an imperative step toward developing a physics-based turbulence parameterization for improving the model prediction of the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon. The primary goal of this experiment is to make long-term observations of detailed evolutions of internal waves, instabilities, and mixing at time scales from 1-min to months and at vertical scales from 0.5 m to O(100) m below the equatorial cold tongue. The tongue of cold water straddling the equator in the eastern Pacific is one of the major sea surface temperature (SST) features influencing tropical air-sea interactions. Vertical turbulent fluxes through the base of the surface mixed layer are major factors in the heat budget that determines SST. Strong turbulence during La Nina cools the mixed layer, strengthening the cold tongue. Weak turbulence during El Nino allows the mixed layer to warm, weakening or erasing the cold tongue. Several periods of intensive microstructure profiling discovered the role of small-scale mixing in modulating the cold tongue, but attempts to parameterize the turbulent fluxes failed because the physics leading to instabilities and turbulence has not been captured by these measurements. Previous observations indicate that internal waves play the key role by providing the finescale shear that trigger instabilities. High spatial and temporal resolutions of measurements, sufficiently capturing instabilities below the cold tongue, are needed, but have not been made.

In the present experiment, shear and strain will be measured at 1-minute intervals over vertical scales of O (1-100) m and turbulent scalar diffusion rates immediately beneath the surface mixed layer in the cold tongue. Co-investigators Moum and Nash at OSU have recently developed a moored microstructure package that can reliably measure turbulent scalar diffusion rates in the equatorial undercurrent. Closely vertically spaced instruments measuring velocity, temperature, salinity and mixing rates will be mounted on a surface mooring. The mooring will be 5 miles from the long-term TAO mooring at 0 140 W. The experiment will be coordinated with another funded observational program. In spring 2008, 10 pods, evenly spaced between 30 and 90-m depth, will be deployed on the long-term TAO mooring at 0 140 W. The deployment will be Immediately with18 days of shipboard microstructure profiler measurements.

Intellectual Merit.
Internal waves produce much of the diapycnal mixing in the ocean and must be understood and quantified before accurate mixing parameterizations can be developed. In the eastern equatorial Pacific, the stratified high-shear zone between the undercurrent core and the base of the mixed layer provides a unique environment for internal waves. Understanding it well enough to accurately parameterize the diapycnal mixing is a major intellectual challenge whose solution will advance the general understanding of internal waves, instabilities, and turbulence, as well as provide necessary support for climate studies.

Broader Impact
This work is expected to lead to more accurate parameterizations of equatorial mixing in general circulation models (GCM) and thus to more realistic climate models. SST, air-sea interaction, and ENSO in the cold tongue are strongly controlled by the turbulence entrainment flux. To improve the large-scale model prediction of ENSO, we need to understand the physics of instabilities and turbulence and improve the turbulence parameterization in GCMs. The proposed project will provide support for the education of a graduate student. The observations and analysis results will be published on a publicly accessible website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The equatorial cold tongue (or cold pool) in the eastern equatorial Pacific has the coolest sea surface temperatures of the equatorial region. The cold tongue has important roles in the dynamics of atmosphere–ocean interactions and in mediating the thermal structure and evolution of the oceanic surface mixed layer in the eastern equatorial Pacific. During La Niña the cold tongue is enhanced and during El Niño it often disappears .

Previous studies report that a strong turbulent entrainment flux, which brings cold water into the surface mixed layer, maintains and modifies the equatorial cold tongue. Abnormal turbulent heat fluxes below the equatorial cold tongue are often associated with ENSO events. Turbulent entrainment fluxes below the equatorial cold tongue observed during La Niña are more than 10 times greater than during El Niño. The physics of the observed variations in turbulent entrainment flux associated with the ENSO, however, are not well understood.

The most significant finding of our research is the strong modulation of equatorial turbulent mixing by tropical instability waves (TIWs); their dynamics are responsible for the observed variation of turbulent entrainment fluxes associated with the ENSO. TIWs are prominent in the central and eastern equatorial Pacific, propagating westward at 0.3–0.5 m s–1 with periods of 15-40 days and wavelengths of ~700-1600 km.

During this research project we collected ~4 months (October 2008 – February 2009) of moored measurements of small-scale shear and stratification, and turbulence in the upper ocean of the central equatorial Pacific. Taken during a later stage of a La Niña, our measurements captured six TIWs and their effects on equatorial turbulence variations. Some significant new findings of this research:

(1)   In the presence of TIWs, turbulence dissipation rates and turbulent heat fluxes in the central equatorial Pacific are 5–10 times greater than previous measurements at the same location but in the absence of TIWs.

(2)   There is a strong vertical divergence of turbulent heat flux, sufficient to heat the core of the Equatorial Undercurrent by 10°K per month.

(3)   Turbulent mixing varies strongly during the four distinct TIW phases. During the northward-to-southward transition of the TIW the reduced shear squared, the thickness of the nighttime surface mixed layer, the penetration depth of the strong turbulence below the base of surface mixed layer (termed deep-cycle turbulence), the turbulent heat flux, and the turbulent kinetic energy are the greatest.

(4)   During the steady southward phase of the TIW the depth of the nighttime surface mixed layer and the deep-cycle turbulence penetration depth are the shallowest. The turbulent heat flux and the turbulent kinetic energy are the weakest.

(5)   A ~50-m thick layer of strong turbulence exists immediately above the core of the Equatorial Undercurrent during the northward-to-southward and steady southward flow phases of the TIW. This strong turbulence layer is decoupled from the deep-cycle turbulence, separated by a thin weak shear layer with no diurnal variation. The turbulence intensity and eddy diffusivity in this deep layer immediately above the core of the Equatorial Undercurrent are comparable to those of the deep-cycle turbulence below the base of the surface mixed layer. This strong deep turbulent layer is presumably caused by the shear instability associated with the Equatorial Undercurrent enhanced by the TIW. However, the exact dynamics of modulation are not yet well understood.
